However, the statement we want to infer is the converse of this contrapositive, which is 'If Joe did not go to the park, then Lucy did not go to the zoo.'

The converse of a conditional statement 'If P, then Q' is 'If Q, then P.' While the contrapositive of a statement is logically equivalent to the original statement, its converse is not.

To determine if the converse is true, we would need additional information because knowing that if one event implies another does not necessarily mean that the absence of the second event implies the absence of the first.
